citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to provide a written program of veterinary care. A written program of veterinary care is
necessary to indicate that care for both the health and well-being of all covered species is provided.
Each exhibitor shall have an attending veterinarian who shall provide adequate veterinary care to its animals in
compliance with this section.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: APRIL 17, 2023

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An adult dromedary camel named Humphrey, was observed to have a severe overgrowth, and swelling of the gums of his
lower jaw. This overgrowth and swelling have caused the displacement of his teeth. Further, the camel was observed
rubbing the overgrown tissue on the wire fence fabric, causing it to bleed.
The licensee contacted a licensed veterinarian, via text, back in February 2023 and the veterinarian stated that the
condition was grave. This camel must be seen by a licensed veterinarian to determine the cause, prognosis, and
treatment for this condition. The licensee shall establish and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care that would
use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include:
The use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of
emergency, weekend, and holiday care.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: MARCH 31, 2023

Records of acquisition were unavailable for review. The record of animals on hand, that was provided, only indicated the
number of cavies, red kangaroo, camel, and ostriches without the required information pertaining to from where they were
acquired. Three lambs and two zebu calves have been born but the births have not been documented.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.
(i) The name and address of the person from whom the animals were purchased or otherwise acquired;
(ii) The USDA license or registration number of the person if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act;
(iii) The vehicle license number and State, and the driver’s license number (or photographic identification card for
nondrivers issued by a State) and State of the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Act;
(iv) The name and address of the person to whom an animal was sold or given;
(v) The date of purchase, acquisition, sale, or disposal of the animal(s);
(vi) The species of the animal(s); and
(vii) The number of animals in the shipment.
Records of acquisition are necessary to ensure that animals have been appropriately obtained.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: APRIL 17, 2023

Housekeeping: Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals
from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be
placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals.
The following items are not clean and/or in disrepair:
• In the sheep enclosure a ladder was stored against the shelter building, a paint tray, numerous strands of colored
bailing twine, a small metal trash can, broken wood pieces, and a wooden top rail plank are present on the ground inside
of both sides of this enclosure.
• A top rail is missing from one section of the sheep enclosure thus leaving this section structurally unsound.
• In the camel enclosure, several fence planks are broken at the front corner, closest to the road. Also, the wire mesh on
this fence, in the same area, has been damaged and lifted up at the base, thus leaving a gap under this enclosure fence.
• In the cavy enclosure, next to the sheep & camel barn, the cavies have dug a hole in the earth thus exposing wire mesh
and a piece of wood with a nail protruding from the end. This opening should be filled in to protect the cavies from getting
injured by the exposed wood and wire mesh.
• The largest cavy enclosure has exposed coated, chicken wire present in the ground around the interior perimeter.
This wire serves as a dig guard. This exposed wire should be covered to prevent injury to the cavies housed therein.
• On the sheep & camel barn, a new metal roof has been installed. However, on the rear corner, a section of metal trim is
not secure and sharp protruding edges are present.
Miscellaneous items within animal enclosures could cause injury or harm to the animals housed inside of the enclosures.
Miscellaneous items should be removed to protect the health and well-being of the animals.
Repairs and/or replacements should be made to all items that are broken or in disrepair to ensure that facilities are in
good repair to protect the health and well-being of the animals.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: APRIL 14, 2023
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee.
End Section

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee was unable to provide a written program of veterinary care.  A written program of veterinary care is 
necessary to indicate that care for both the health and well-being of all covered species is provided. 
 
Each exhibitor shall have an attending veterinarian who shall provide adequate veterinary care to its animals in 
compliance with this section. 
 
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time 
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary 
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY:  APRIL 17, 2023 
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
An adult dromedary camel named Humphrey, was observed to have a severe overgrowth, and swelling of the gums of his 
lower jaw.  This overgrowth and swelling have caused the displacement of his teeth.  Further, the camel was observed

rubbing the overgrown tissue on the wire fence fabric, causing it to bleed.   
 
The licensee contacted a licensed veterinarian, via text, back in February 2023 and the veterinarian stated that the 
condition was grave. This camel must be seen by a licensed veterinarian to determine the cause, prognosis, and 
treatment for this condition.  The licensee shall establish and maintain an adequate program of veterinary care that would 
use the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include:  
The use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of 
emergency, weekend, and holiday care. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY:  MARCH 31, 2023 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Records of acquisition were unavailable for review.    The record of animals on hand, that was provided, only indicated the 
number of cavies, red kangaroo, camel, and ostriches without the required information pertaining to from where they were 
acquired. Three lambs and two zebu calves have been born but the births have not been documented.  
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make, 
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other 
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.

(i) The name and address of the person from whom the animals were purchased or otherwise acquired;  
(ii) The USDA license or registration number of the person if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act;  
(iii) The vehicle license number and State, and the driver’s license number (or photographic identification card for 
nondrivers issued by a State) and State of the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Act;  
(iv) The name and address of the person to whom an animal was sold or given;  
(v) The date of purchase, acquisition, sale, or disposal of the animal(s);  
(vi) The species of the animal(s); and  
(vii) The number of animals in the shipment. 
Records of acquisition are necessary to ensure that animals have been appropriately obtained. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY:  APRIL 17, 2023 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
Housekeeping:  Premises (buildings and grounds) shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the animals 
from injury and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Accumulations of trash shall be 
placed in designated areas and cleared as necessary to protect the health of the animals. 
 
The following items are not clean and/or in disrepair: 
•  In the sheep enclosure a ladder was stored against the shelter building, a paint tray, numerous strands of colored 
bailing twine, a small metal trash can, broken wood pieces, and a wooden top rail plank are present on the ground inside 
of both sides of this enclosure.

• A top rail is missing from one section of the sheep enclosure thus leaving this section structurally unsound. 
 
• In the camel enclosure, several fence planks are broken at the front corner, closest to the road.  Also, the wire mesh on 
this fence, in the same area, has been damaged and lifted up at the base, thus leaving a gap under this enclosure fence. 
 
• In the cavy enclosure, next to the sheep & camel barn, the cavies have dug a hole in the earth thus exposing wire mesh 
and a piece of wood with a nail protruding from the end.  This opening should be filled in to protect the cavies from getting 
injured by the exposed wood and wire mesh. 
 
•  The largest cavy enclosure has exposed coated, chicken wire present in the ground around the interior perimeter.  
This wire serves as a dig guard.  This exposed wire should be covered to prevent injury to the cavies housed therein.  
 
• On the sheep & camel barn, a new metal roof has been installed.  However, on the rear corner, a section of metal trim is 
not secure and sharp protruding edges are present. 
 
Miscellaneous items within animal enclosures could cause injury or harm to the animals housed inside of the enclosures. 
Miscellaneous items should be removed to protect the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
Repairs and/or replacements should be made to all items that are broken or in disrepair to ensure that facilities are in 
good repair to protect the health and well-being of the animals. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: APRIL 14, 2023

This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End Section
